nameEntry.part: Western Australian Government Records relating to Child Welfare and Protection

biogHist.abstract: Western Australian Government Records relating to Child Welfare and Protection is a collection dating back to 1894. It is held by Child Protection and Family Support (CPFS). The collection includes records from the Government Receiving Depot, the State Children's Department, the Child Welfare Department and more recent departments which have been known at different times as the Department for Child Protection, Community Development, Community Welfare, Community Services, and Family and Children's Services. The records relate to children who were placed in all types of out of home 'care' in Western Australia. Some of the records held by the CPFS were originally created by another government department or private agency.
biogHist.p: Access to these records is restricted and confidentiality is protected by the Department. If you believe the Department may hold records about you, or about a family member, you are encouraged to apply. Access is governed by the Freedom of Information Act 1992 and the Department has a form on their website which you must use to apply for records.
The types of records held by the Department include admission book registers, individual files, adoption placements and Children's Court registers.

'In the past, many people were separated from their families due to policies and practices which reflected the social attitudes of those times. As a result many people do not know their relatives, their own background, childhood or family history. Files are limited in the amount and type of information they hold. This is because the information which was recorded depended on the extent of contact with the person or the family. Sometimes records are incomplete, have pages missing or the writing has deteriorated and is unreadable, and some files have been destroyed. The Department is making every effort to preserve the remaining records. Department for Child Protection, 2011.'

descriptiveNote.p: No records created by the Cockburn Youth Services Association are known to exist. However, Western Australian Government Records relating to Child Welfare and Protection may include records for young people referred to Cockburn House by child welfare authorities.

descriptiveNote.p: Youth justice records before July 1994 have been under the control of the child welfare authorities. People who are looking for youth detention records should contact the Department for Child Protection and Family Support for pre-July 1994 records and the Department for Corrective Services for post-July 1994 records.

descriptiveNote.p: The Hillcrest Records Collection is a separate collection held by Child Protection and Family Support within the Western Australian Government Records relating to Child Welfare and Protection. One reason for this is that many young women who were Wards were admitted to Hillcrest to have their babies.

descriptiveNote.p: The Department for Child Protection and Family Support held the Western Australian Government Records relating to Child Welfare and Protection until 1 July 2017.

descriptiveNote.p: Western Australian Government Records relating to Child Welfare and Protection includes an index of some clients who sought assistance through Pregnancy Help. The index contains the mother's name, and sometimes the child's name and date of birth.

resourceRelation.relationEntry: The Christian Brothers' Agricultural School, Tardun, Western Australia

archref.unittitle: The Christian Brothers' Agricultural School, Tardun, Western Australia
archref.abstract:
'The Christian Brothers' Agricultural School Tardun Western Australia' is a digital copy of a booklet held by the Department of Communities. The booklet is undated but a handwritten note on the front cover is dated 1936. It appears to be a prospectus, written to advertise the perceived benefits of the 'Tardun Scheme' and attract donors. The 20-page booklet contains many photographs of boys and notable benefactors.
There is a detailed description of the education and training program at the Tardun Farm School, and the boys' progression from Castledare, to Clontarf and on to Tardun - including information about government subsidies and service wages.
Photographs include farm buildings and activities at Tardun, such as 'Benito Boy' (a prize stallion), the original buildings, first group of trainees at Tardun, and the dam.
There are also photographs of the Clontarf Band, manual arts room and beehives, and images of Castledare including Matron and boys, and scenes of the buildings.
archref.note: Reproduced with the kind permission of the Department of Communities, Western Australia
